Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Story: I stared at my phone, a message from my granddaughter lighting up the screen. She’d just started her new job, and the family group chat was buzzing with her excitement. I knew she’d want to talk, to share every detail, and I wanted to be there for her, to listen and celebrate. But my laptop chimed insistently—Slack messages piling up, architects from three different teams waiting for my input on the new feature set. The launch date had been moved up, and everyone was blocked until I made some decisions. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of family and the pressure of work. I could almost hear my daughter’s voice reminding me how much it means to the kids when I’m present, but the anxious faces of my colleagues flashed in my mind too, counting on me to keep the project moving. My heart ached with the weight of both worlds, each demanding my attention, each unwilling to wait.
